channel.title: Comments on: John Connelly’s new book about Mgsr. Oesterreicher
channel.description: notes on Jewish theology and spirituality

item.title: By: Yehudah Mirsky
item.dc:creator: Yehudah Mirsky
item.description: For whatever it's worth, my father had very warm relations with Oesterreicher - for all I know that may have largely been because of the latter's being supportive, as I recall, of Israel and Zionism. Oesterreicher co-edited a volume on Jerusalem under the auspices of the now-defunct American Professors for Peace in the Middle East, in which my father was very involved. (While we're at it, it's sometimes occurred to me that there may be an interesting paper or part of an MA thesis to be done on APPME as an admittedly minor but perhaps illustrative way-station en route to the ideological fissures of today.)

item.title: By: Alan Brill
item.dc:creator: Alan Brill
item.description: Larry, that is correct. He was suspect and critiqued by the Jewish community, in the press, and by Jewish thinkers. Connelly's point is that nevertheless he was using Theme's words. The book was based on his writings in Paris 47-52. He arrived in the US in 52. His 1953 writings already sound different. He never wrote like that again but he never really regained anyone's trust. The Forward did not ask me what I thought of the book but how people will relate to these "new" revelations.

item.title: By: Lawrence Kaplan
item.dc:creator: Lawrence Kaplan
item.description: Oesterreicher's book of 1952,Walls Are Crumbling: Seven Jewish Philosophers Discover Christ was clearly conversionary. Note the date, however. It was the subject to an extremely harsh review by Trude Weiss Rosmarin's in her journal The Jewish Spectator-- I don't remember when. (A very interesting journal, by the way. It would be good subject for a thesis.) Oesterreicher wrote a reply and Weiss Rosmarin an even sharper response. It still resonates in my memory.
